page.title: 08Wild Life
page.content: This area of the North York Moor National Park abounds in wild life. The wild moorland is the home of grouse and pheasants, rabbits, hares and the only poisonous snake in England, the Adder. The forest areas are the homes of foxes, birds, squirrels and deer. The Red Grouse amd Pheasants attract the attention of sportsmen who help in the conservation of the area by rearing birds every year and releasing them on the moor. Foxes are not welcomed by the farmers as they do much damage at the farms by killing chickens and ducks. Many birds nest in the trees including woodpeckers, snipe, sparrows, blue and great tits, tawny and barn owls. Sparrow hawks can be seen hovering over the moor looking for food.
